topic: The Gentleman vs The Petty Person
conclusion: The gentleman (junzi) is distinguished not by birth but by moral cultivation and virtuous conduct

topic: The Gentleman vs The Petty Person
conclusion: The petty person (xiaoren) is concerned with profit; the gentleman is concerned with righteousness

topic: The Gentleman vs The Petty Person
conclusion: The gentleman seeks to perfect himself; the petty person seeks to perfect others through blame

topic: The Gentleman vs The Petty Person
conclusion: The gentleman is at ease without being arrogant; the petty person is arrogant without being at ease

topic: The Gentleman vs The Petty Person
conclusion: The gentleman makes demands on himself; the petty person makes demands on others

topic: The Gentleman vs The Petty Person
conclusion: The gentleman is inclusive and not partisan; the petty person is partisan and not inclusive
Ren (humaneness/benevolence) is the supreme virtue from which all other virtues derive their meaning
To practice ren is to love others and to treat them with the consideration one would wish for oneself
Ren cannot be achieved through momentary acts but requires sustained commitment throughout one's life
The person of ren, wishing to establish himself, establishes others; wishing to develop himself, develops others
Ren is never far away; if I desire ren, then ren is at hand
To overcome the self and return to ritual propriety constitutes ren
Li (ritual propriety) provides the external forms through which inner virtue is expressed and cultivated
Without li, respectfulness becomes laborious bustle; caution becomes timidity; courage becomes insubordination; straightforwardness becomes rudeness
Li originated from the sage-kings and embodies accumulated wisdom about proper human conduct
The spirit of li matters more than its outward observance; ritual without reverence is empty formalism
Li serves to regulate the emotions, channeling them into appropriate expressions rather than suppressing them
The rites of mourning exist not merely for the dead but to cultivate and express filial devotion in the living
Filial piety (xiao) is the root of all virtue and the foundation of moral education
Serving one's parents with genuine reverence distinguishes human filial piety from the mere feeding that animals provide their young
Filial piety requires not just obedience but gentle remonstrance when parents err
The family is the primary school of virtue; proper relations within the family extend outward to proper relations in society
A son should not travel far while his parents are alive; if he must travel, he must have a definite destination
Three years of mourning for deceased parents reflects the three years of helpless infancy when parents carried the child
Rectification of names (zhengming) is the first task of governance; when names are not correct, language is not in accord with truth
When language is not in accord with truth, affairs cannot be accomplished
A ruler must be a true ruler, a minister a true minister, a father a true father, a son a true son
Social disorder originates in the corruption of language and the failure of names to correspond to realities
To call something by its proper name is already to begin the work of moral and political reform
The gentleman is cautious in speech precisely because words carry moral weight and practical consequence
Government by moral virtue is like the North Star, which remains in its place while all other stars revolve around it
Lead the people with governmental measures and regulate them with punishments, and they will avoid wrongdoing but have no sense of shame
Lead them with virtue and regulate them with li, and they will have a sense of shame and moreover will become good
The ruler who governs by virtue is like the wind; the common people are like grass—when the wind blows, the grass bends
If a ruler himself is upright, all will go well without orders; if he is not upright, his orders will not be obeyed
Good government consists in the ruler being a ruler, the minister being a minister, the father being a father, and the son being a son
The art of governance is to attract people from afar through virtue and to make those nearby content
A state can survive without sufficient arms; a state can survive without sufficient food; but a state cannot survive without the trust of the people
Learning without thought is labor lost; thought without learning is perilous
By nature, people are similar; by practice, they become different
Education should be provided to all, without distinction of class
The superior teacher adapts his instruction to the capacity and disposition of each student
I do not enlighten those who are not eager to learn, nor do I instruct those who are not anxious to express their ideas
When I have pointed out one corner of a square to someone and he does not come back with the other three, I will not repeat myself
In a hamlet of ten families, there are bound to be those as loyal and trustworthy as I, but none as fond of learning
To study and at due times to practice what one has learned—is this not a pleasure?
At fifteen I set my heart on learning; at thirty I took my stand; at forty I was no longer perplexed
At fifty I knew the will of Heaven; at sixty my ear was attuned; at seventy I could follow my heart's desire without overstepping the bounds
Self-cultivation is a lifelong process that proceeds through identifiable stages of moral development
The gentleman does not grieve that people do not recognize his merits; he grieves that he has no merits to be recognized
To see what is right and not do it is cowardice
The gentleman is distressed by his own lack of ability, not by the failure of others to recognize him
When you see a worthy person, think of becoming his equal; when you see an unworthy person, examine yourself inwardly
The gentleman is ashamed to let his words outrun his deeds
Do not do to others what you would not have them do to you
Shu (reciprocity) is the one word that can serve as a guide to conduct throughout one's life
Reciprocity is not mere calculation but arises from genuine fellow-feeling and imagination of others' conditions
Zhong (loyalty to one's best self) and shu (reciprocity) together constitute the Way
To practice shu requires that one first understand one's own heart before one can understand the hearts of others
Heaven does not speak, yet the four seasons proceed and the hundred things are born
The gentleman stands in awe of three things: the will of Heaven, great persons, and the words of the sages
The petty person, not knowing the will of Heaven, does not stand in awe of it
If Heaven wished the Way to perish, it would not have given it to us; since Heaven has not yet destroyed the Way, what can the people of Kuang do to me?
One should respect the spirits but keep them at a distance; wisdom lies in this
When you do not yet understand life, how can you understand death?
The sacrificial rites should be performed as if the spirits were present
Yi (righteousness) is the standard by which the gentleman measures all actions
The gentleman understands yi; the petty person understands profit
Wealth and honor obtained through unrighteous means are to me like floating clouds
The gentleman is not a utensil; his worth is not limited to a single function
When it is possible to act, act; when it is not possible to act, withdraw
The gentleman takes rightness as his substance, practices it according to li, brings it forth in modesty, and completes it with faithfulness
In the presence of a worthy person, one should think of equaling him; in the presence of an unworthy person, one should turn inward and examine oneself
Zhi (wisdom) is knowing others; ren is loving others
To know what you know and what you do not know—this is true knowledge
The wise find pleasure in water; the benevolent find pleasure in mountains; the wise are active; the benevolent are tranquil
There are those who act without understanding; I am not one of them
Hearing much, setting aside what is doubtful, and speaking cautiously of the rest reduces occasions for blame
The wise are free from perplexity; the benevolent are free from anxiety; the courageous are free from fear
I am not one who was born with knowledge; I love antiquity and earnestly seek knowledge therein
Music and li are intimately connected; li regulates external conduct while music harmonizes the inner self
The proper music elevates the spirit and refines the emotions; improper music leads to moral dissolution
Poetry can be used to stimulate the mind, to train in self-contemplation, to cultivate sociability, and to express grievances
One is roused by the Odes, established by li, and perfected by music
The ancient kings established music to glorify their achievements and to elevate the moral character of the people
When the Way prevails in the world, the common people do not discuss politics
If one hears the Way in the morning, one may die content in the evening
The Way is not far from human beings; a way that is far from human beings cannot be the true Way
It is not that I do not like the Way but that I lack the strength to follow it; those who truly lack the strength collapse along the way—you draw the line beforehand
The Way of the gentleman is threefold, and I have not attained it: the benevolent have no worries, the wise have no perplexities, the courageous have no fears
Friendship with the upright, the truthful, and the learned is beneficial; friendship with the fawning, the two-faced, and the glib-tongued is harmful
Have no friends who are not your equal
The gentleman associates but does not form cliques; the petty person forms cliques but does not associate
To have friends come from afar—is this not a joy?
Do not worry about not being recognized by others; worry about failing to recognize others
Speak loyally to your friends and guide them skillfully; if that fails, stop—do not bring disgrace upon yourself
With coarse rice to eat, water to drink, and my bent arm for a pillow, I still find happiness
Riches and honors that are obtained unjustly are like floating clouds to me
How admirable Hui was! A handful of rice, a gourd of water, living in a mean street—others would find it unbearable, but Hui did not let it affect his joy
The gentleman is calm and at ease; the petty person is always anxious and worried
I have never refused instruction to anyone who came to me with a bundle of dried meat
